data.text: What Is the Average Speed and Distance per Day when Bike Touring?

Hey guys, What is your average speed and distance per day? I ride about 25km/h when i dont have to stop on my mtb and i do like 150km per day (which i know is not a lot but i do some other stuff when im not biking)
Avg about 80 miles a day at 15mph while on loaded tour
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: how do you deal with mussel recovery for the next day?
data.author: David Quast

data.text: A lot of sleep and compression pants help.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: My max speed was 45 km/HR and that was when a wild dog was trying to catch up my bike..
data.author: Jorginho Reideroma

data.text: When I used my road bike and travelled very light I averaged 30 km/h and was doing 150km a day. On my gravel/touring bike with more equipment I averaged 22km/h and was doing 125km day I just got a recumbent trike a couple weeks ago to use on tours to ease stress in back. Without anything on it and just out for rides I get about 22km/h. So next tour will probably be a bit slower with all equipment and doing long days. I need more training but if I can get close to 20km/h on trike and do about 120km day I will be happy.
data.author: Duane Taylor

data.text: One day 16 or 22km/h and 60 or 80 or 120 kilometers. On another day sometimes more or less. I don't care about numbers anymore.
data.author: Heuer Andy

data.text: 15 km/h with full pack 20-25 km with no bags
data.author: Mathieu Ledoux

data.text:
I average about 3-5 mph and 15-20 miles per day. That said, I'm travelling super heavy with a dog trailer and do lots of walking/pushing while the dogs walk beside me. https://pedals4paws.com
Pedals4Paws - Bike Touring With Dogs
pedals4paws.com
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: Put fast rolling / semi slick tyres
data.author: Mahesh T Pai

data.text: last year went loaded with a gravel bike 90% road (some badly maintained ) about avg 25 km/h. Recently I have been travelling lighter with a gravel more suited for the offroad . In the forests and sand sometimes avg 10km/h. on flat road up to avg 33km/h. I normally average in the lower 20s. Distance depends on weather and terrain. Sometimes up to 250km sometimes about 80km.

data.text: The whole idea is to tour , and see thing , that also means not going in a straight line , even spend a day or two off the bike on foot to see things. Distance would range from 0 km - 120 km per day all depending on what's there to see

data.text: 15 to 18 kilometres an hour. And typically around 100 kilometres per day. I like to stroll and take my time to say hello to the people I pass.

data.text: I‚Äôm in no rush and average maybe 10-12km/hr including frequent stops to eat and smell the roses.

data.text: It all depends on the terrain and the amount of gear you bring along.

data.text: I have no idea and I don't much care ü§™

data.text: Why would you need to know the answer to this question?
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: I am lucky to reach 20kph. Under perfect conditions - a straight, flat, wide, smooth road I might be able to get near 30kph. I plan for 120-130km legs occasionally stretching out to 200km.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: We only do 80 kms per day, at a speed of 20 per hour. We see sights on the way, visit villages and towns. At a slow pace. We are both > 60.
data.author: Nel Verhoeven

data.text: I average about 10mph and do between 30 and 40 miles on a day ride. Like to stop/start to. Photo opportunities and food stops. üôÇ

data.text: With all possible respect, who cares? Enjoy the journey is all üëç

data.text: What is the purpose of your question?
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: NOT a lot? üòÇ I think I average about 75. 90 on paved roads and 50-60 on sandy tracks.
data.author: Lars Bengtsson

data.text: I've only known my speed since my kids made me get strava on the phone. I'm over 65 I don't care, non of us in this group are tour de france competitors. Do what makes you happy, numbers will spoil your fun. If you have a day where your perceived effort doesn't match you actual you could become disheartened
data.author: John Axson

data.text: 150km is alot my friend especially with fully loaded bike with front and rear panniers i do between 60 to 130 a day depending on the terrain weather etc its not a race i keep about 6 to 8 hours of riding each day
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Why live by the numbers which is just another form of social enslavement the idea is to be free..........
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: If you think 150 km/day is "not a lot," you have a problem. Or you're into racing, which has little to do with touring. I sometimes "brag" about the kms I've done over the 11 years I've been a nomadic cyclist/translator and language teacher (+/- 48.000 km, though I could be a thousand or more kms off, it's not so exact) and the number of countries (38 cycling many more without cycling), but I do it more than anything else to (maybe?) connect with like-minded people, or to define my lifestyle, I guess. To calculate a day's ride (just as an example) I figure 10 km/hr, that is, if I want to do 60 km or 80 km, then I figure I will be on the road some 6 or 8 hours. My average when touring is a about 70 km/day, though recently it went down to 40 km/day, in Mexico. 10 km per hour, including stops for photos, snacks, even long stops for lunch, drying out the gear, etc. When touring, I average 1.000 km/month, sometimes only 600 km, sometimes 1.500 km. It all depends. There's the weather, the terrain (flat/mountainous), my condition, my work load (I bike and work at the same time), and especially the season of the year, as the daylight hours in summer are way more than in winter! I think the only point to this post (hopefully) is to realize that there are as many answers as there are people. Each person finds out what is "right" for them, or what has been typical (average), and even that is relative because it changes! So there's not much significant to be said in the end, is there? Just an exercise in writing, grammar, spelling, sentence structure.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I see no reason in keeping record of it but 150 km a day doesn't leave time to interact and see / visit something. Not much about bike touring.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: 150 km is already quite a lot on a MTB. That probably equals the double on a fast roadbike. I habe done so far a 100 km on a MTB at an average speed of slow 15,2 km/h. You are having a good speed already. Myself, I don't care about distance or speed. I go at slow speed of fun as I could do 65 km every day on a fully loaded MTB (bikepacking). My favourite saying: It is not about miles, it is about smiles. But people have diverent goals, so distance and speed may make them happy.
data.author: Beat Wenzinger

data.text: Everyone has different goals/objectives: touring/relaxing, personal challenge with more speed/performance... There is room enough for everyone to enjoy bike touring as he likes it, I find it kind of pointless to compare. Also, high figures could discourage beginners whou could feel they are not up to the impressive challenge. I usually ride for 6-7 hours a day, with as many stops as needed, depending on fatigue, fitness, load, terrain, weather... between 60-100 km/day maybe? The longest I rode must have been around 120 km in one day. I am not fit at all currently, so riding for even 60 km in one day would be a real challenge! The good thing is that you get back into shape super fast on a bike. The most important in my opinion, would be to make it so it remains enjoyable and not a chore! Enjoy the views, food and people! :)
data.author: Eric Escolano Del Valle

data.text: Well said, thank you!
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: OP, what do you use for measure and average? 150km without stopping on mtb seems stretched. I have done 170+ km stretches, with stops, through gravel rocks and singletracks before, it was a mission, it took me over 12 hours, riding in pitch dark on my 26 inch bike. On my newer gravel bike with packs, I mostly average 20km/h, this includes all roads and winds. Took me 5h30m to reach 100km yesterday abd day before that, this is riding time on my spidometer. Add 2 hours on top for stops, food and looking around.
data.author: Taavi Viikman

data.text: Get there when I get there.
data.author: Annie Mtb North

data.text: There are many factors affecting speed. For context, I am an older guy and not super fit, but I do ride 40-60 km regularly. Maybe 2-3 times per week. On my unloaded 700c hybrid I will average 20 kph. I will do 40km with minimum breaks. On my 1/2 loaded 26" touring bike, I ride easy. I stop regularly to take a photo, smell the flowers, have a drink, answer calls of nature. Where I live is not flat, but even on flatter areas on a short day ride I will average 15-20 kph. On a long day ride, I will take a 2 hour lunch break, cook lunch, wash the dishes, and play my ukulele while my food digests. On those days I will probably ride for 60km in 4 1/2 hours riding, that is about 13kph. I can maintain that pace easily day after day. The longest I have done in a day's touring is 120 km. That was out of necessity. I am also aware that 120km in a day is totally different to 120km per day, for several days.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: that's the spirit. We would get along easily!

data.text: I'm startled that some people do 100/day for days and weeks on end. They usually are not carrying anything though and have support.

data.text: i dont have support, but indeed, i dont carry a lot. Just a sleeping bag and a new set of underwear

data.text: I used to average between 80 km and 120:km with a load of 17 kilos. I made sure not to exceed 20 kmh so as not to tier too early . I made several trips on the bicycle. I used to take a day off every 3 days.

data.text: It doesn't matter. I stop whenever I see a nice spot to eat/camp or chill.

data.text: Since ride-by shooting is the primary goal -- photography, that is -- I aim for around 80 km a day, depends on where my next bivouac is though. Speed? Dunno, I like to smell the roses along the way.

data.text: Less is better i do 6 or 7 per hour,and fully loaded.

data.text: yep! Agreed. There‚Äôs more to experience and need to do after the ride, important not to rush the recovery and savoring.

data.text: I average around the 25 km/h for my daily 60 or 50 km ride. Its a lot slower now i am 75 i used to be able to cruise at 35 in my youth. Things change, i used to ride out to find hills to climb now i avoid them if possible.

data.text: Never more than 15kms/hr. Distance up to 70 kms. What's the hurry?

data.text: About 4 months in our Amazing World Bike Tour fully loaded about 45 to 50 kg (incl. food and water) per bicycle we average about 13 km/h and around 65 km/day right now in Turkey üáπüá∑. We try to start riding very early in the day because especially after noon the heat is very intense.

data.text: hello, I also suggest the free MakeYourTripBetter website to put you directly in touch with the many locals or other travelers who enjoy the same things as you. they will certainly have very good advice

data.text: Some Years ago in Italy an local cyclist helped me find a good cyclepath (I was on tour) While we drove, he pointed at me, because I said I do only 100km a day. I was so dump to get influenced by thatüòÅ, since then trying to do 120/130 or even more fully packed! These days I‚Äòm on a 4day Tour in black forest germany, riding about 70km a dayüòä. I enjoy it a lot. But, I get close to 50years, so I try do take it bit more easy.

data.text: Downhill up to 40km/h, uphill around 10km/h üòâ If really needed (depends on the place, where I can stay) up to 110km/h, but I prefer around 80km/day. I like to look around and see the nature, special nice buildings etc. If I'm in the mood I take 1 hours rests, mostly 30min/rests two or three times a day. I am 71-y-o, ride an e-bicycle and ride only on tarmac och paved roads. I only have ca 15kg load, but my bicycle has a weight of 25kg.

data.text: ...which I know is not a lot...Are you deliberately trying to troll in here? You are shaming people, you do realise this.

data.text: I tend to think how far I'd be willing to ride in a cold, rainy, windy day and keep that at my upper limit.

data.text: Good until I see a bird or a coffee shop

data.text: 150km per day is a lot, unless you have a strong tail-wind. Over 12-ish km/hr, the wind resistance increases substantially. I usually prefer to be around the 12km/hr and just ride more hours to get the 100km/day. I got nothing else to day anyway!
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: With little training, we averaged 70 km / day on a 1500km tour with lots of hills. We enjoyed just making progress, and the stops. Being able to look at the map and see how far we had come was very rewarding.
data.author: Sam Mojel
